content: I'm moving to Okinawa, Japan soon. I'm on holiday just sorting some stuff out here military wise. This phrase book is very helpful especially when my social anxiety spikes up as the phrasebook says it for me (I'm extremely embarrassed about not being understandable). I've got other versions of the phrasebook as I travel alot also. Extremely helpful would always recommend!

Just right! Excellent! I've been in at least 18 countries where English was not the main language, so I know what words and phrases are the most useful. Seriously, about a dozen phrases are all most people will need for tourism. This app covers them all and hundreds more. "Heart" the ones you will need most. It has all 4 important features: English phrase, Japanese phrase in our alphabet, spoken Japanese, and phrase written in Japanese so you can show it to a Japanese person. Buy it!
came in handy in japan if I could remember a phrase. I recommend this alongside genki 1 and 2

I have been living in Japan for over a year. I recently had a medical emergency at Yokohama train station involving my heart. I was able to use the app to communicate "Call a doctor!". They called an ambulance and I was rushed to the hospital in time to survive. Without this app I might not be alive today. It has also helped me tremendously in my daily life. My highest recommendation and gratitude!

I am still new to using it, but it could earn 5 stars. The only thing it is missing is the Japanese to English alphabet translation. I would like to be able to type in the Japanese words, so that I can translate text.

I remember how scared I was to go to Japan. I didn't know anything in Japanese and it would probably seem foreign to me. I'm a Jamaican and I know Patoi, English AND Spanish. This app gave me a step up in learning Japanese and now I'm fluent in the language. Now I can communicate with the Japanese students at my school! And now I can go to Japan without fear. :) JAPAN HERE I COME.

Good things are: lots of phrases, search function, audio, and presented in a way that you can quiz yourself.  However, the BAD thing is it uses formal speech way too much.  Japanese mainly use INFORMAL speech and verb conjugations.  Therefore, a lot of what you practice will be correct, BUT NOT commonly spoken by Japanese.  Formal speaking patterns are only used in more special situations by Japanese, like when talking to their company president or old people, not with peers or friends.

Very handy and useful, best app of its kind, but some are wrong. "Koucya" is wrong for "tea," or out of style. O-cha is the correct pronunciation for tea. Also, it's not incorrect to say "shibaraku desu" to mean "long time" as in since we last met, but it is awkward since it doesn't invite conversation. This is based on 2 months of living in Tokyo with a partner that is native-english, and proficient in Japanese.
